title: Ear, Nose, Mouth, and Throat Disorders

title.__html: Ear, Nose, Mouth, and Throat Disorders

children: Ear, Nose, Mouth, and Throat Disorders

An estimated 50% of adults aged 60 to 69 years in the United States have hearing loss that affects their day-to-day communication. Hearing loss is underrecognized by patients and physicians and can negatively affect relationships and lead to social isolation and reduced quality of life. It is associated with higher rates of unemployment, depression, dementia, hospitalization, falls, functional decline, and death.
Hearing loss is categorized according to the anatomic deficit: conductive (outer or middle ear), sensorineural (inner ear), or mixed
. Conductive hearing loss is caused by obstruction or pathology of the outer or middle ear (such as cholesteatoma,

that prevents sound transmission and is more often associated with pain or ear drainage. Sensorineural hearing loss is caused by disorders of the cochlea, auditory nerve, and central nervous system and is more often accompanied by tinnitus or vertigo. For discussion of vertigo, see

. Such medications as aminoglycosides, tetracycline, chemotherapeutic agents (cisplatin, carboplatin, 5-fluorouracil, bleomycin), high-dose aspirin, and NSAIDs may cause hearing loss. Although hearing loss is associated with loop diuretics, it is often temporary in the absence of other ototoxic medications. Genetics is implicated in hearing loss and plays a role in 25% to 50% of adult-onset hearing loss.

According to the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommendations, evidence is insufficient to assess the benefits and harms of screening for hearing loss in asymptomatic adults aged 50 years or older. Simple and effective tests, such as evaluating whether a patient can hear a whispered voice or single-question screening (for example, “Do you have difficulty with your hearing?”), can be performed in the office. Additional in-office screening maneuvers are described in
. In patients with identified hearing loss, physical examination should include otoscopic examination as well as the Weber and Rinne tests

to differentiate conductive from sensorineural hearing loss. Routine referral to an audiologist is indicated when hearing loss is identified. Imaging (typically MRI) is rarely required unless the hearing loss is acute and unilateral or associated with other neurologic changes. Sudden-onset hearing loss (within 72 hours) requires more urgent referral to an audiologist and MRI of the retrocochlear structures.

Treatment options for hearing loss include hearing-assistive devices, hearing aids, and cochlear implants. Many varieties of hearing-assistive devices exist, and they can be linked with hearing aids. Examples include amplified telephones, notification systems, personal amplifiers, and television streamers. Use of hearing aids is low owing to patient barriers that include cost, stigma, cosmetic appearance, perceived ineffectiveness, and physical discomfort in wearing them. Treatment of sudden sensorineural hearing loss may include oral glucocorticoids within 2 weeks of onset, although strong evidence of efficacy is lacking.

Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma) is an uncommon cause of hearing loss but should be considered in patients presenting with chronic progressive unilateral hearing loss. Most are of unknown etiology but they can be associated with neurofibromatosis type 2. Involvement of the cochlear nerve often causes tinnitus in addition to the hearing loss and, less frequently, vestibular nerve involvement may cause imbalance and gait instability. Unilateral sensineural hearing loss is confirmed with audiometry and MRI is the diagnostic test of choice. Surgical resection is the most common treatment, but radiation therapy is also effective. Observation is an option is patients with small tumors not causing significant symptoms, but serial MRIs and hearing assessments are necessary to assess for progression.

Simple and effective tests for hearing loss, such as evaluating whether a patient can hear a whispered voice or single-question screening (for example, “Do you have difficulty with your hearing?”), can be performed in the office.
Sudden-onset hearing loss (within 72 hours) requires urgent referral to an audiologist, MRI of the retrocochlear structures, and consideration of oral glucocorticoids.

Tinnitus is the conscious perception of sound (most commonly buzzing or ringing) without an external source. The history should include onset, duration, quality (including pulsatile nature and laterality), associated symptoms (such as hearing loss, vertigo, imbalance, depression, or anxiety), noise and medication exposures (such as loop diuretics or aminoglycosides), and the effect on quality of life. Physical examination should include otoscopy, auscultation over the periauricular region and neck for vascular lesions, and neurologic examination. Audiologic assessment is reasonable for patients presenting with tinnitus, but prompt assessment, imaging, and evaluation by an otolaryngologist should be considered in patients with unilateral or pulsatile tinnitus, asymmetric or sudden hearing loss, or focal neurologic symptoms.

Treatment involves addressing the underlying condition, including insomnia and depression, which can worsen tinnitus. Medications and herbal supplements have not been shown to be beneficial. Hearing aids may be helpful in treating tinnitus associated with hearing loss by producing a masking effect. Similarly, sound therapy, which includes masking of the tinnitus with external sound generators, may be helpful for persistent, bothersome tinnitus, providing relief from the related stress and management of the perception of tinnitus. Cognitive behavioral therapy is an effective therapy for tinnitus but may be limited by availability and lack of reimbursement.

Patients with acute otitis media (AOM) usually present with unilateral ear pain and diminished hearing along with bulging or intense erythema of the tympanic membrane. Otitis media with effusion is often mistaken for AOM in adults

; it is characterized by the presence of fluid in the middle ear without acute inflammation or signs of systemic illness. AOM is rare in adults, and although numerous guidelines exist for treatment of AOM in children, management in adults is less clear. The Choosing Wisely Canada initiative recommends observation initially for uncomplicated AOM in adults and children. If antibiotics are prescribed, amoxicillin or amoxicillin-clavulanic acid provides coverage for the most common organisms. Fever, posterior ear pain, and facial nerve paralysis are rare but suggest complications, such as mastoiditis, and may require urgent imaging and surgical consultation. Patients with recurrent AOM or persistent hearing loss should be referred to an otolaryngologist.

is diffuse inflammation of the external ear canal and may involve the pinna and tragus, with rapid onset within the preceding 3 weeks. In 98% of cases of AOE, the cause is bacterial infection, most commonly with

. Symptoms include otalgia, pruritus, and ear fullness. The history should include assessment for immunocompromising conditions (such as diabetes mellitus, HIV infection, or cancer chemotherapy); history of radiation; and tympanostomy tubes or perforation of the tympanic membrane, which may alter choice of treatment. On physical examination, the classic sign of AOE is tenderness with pushing on the tragus or pulling on the pinna.

Topical treatments, including antibiotics, glucocorticoids, antiseptics (acetic acid), and combination therapies, are first-line management for uncomplicated AOE; systemic antibiotics are ineffective and should be avoided. Quinolone drops are preferred in the case of a nonintact tympanic membrane. Patients should be instructed on proper technique for instillation of ear drops, including cleaning excess debris before instilling the drops and then lying down with the affected ear facing upward, remaining in this position for 3 to 5 minutes. Immunocompromised patients require topical and systemic therapy and are at increased risk for deeper infections, including bone involvement (malignant otitis externa), which requires urgent referral to an otolaryngologist.

The Choosing Wisely Canada initiative recommends observation initially for uncomplicated acute otitis media in adults and children; if antibiotics are prescribed, amoxicillin or amoxicillin-clavulanic acid provides coverage for the most common organisms.
Topical treatments, including antibiotics, glucocorticoids, antiseptics (acetic acid), and combination therapies, are first-line management for uncomplicated acute otitis externa.

Cerumen helps to protect, clean, and lubricate the external auditory canal. Its normal expulsion, assisted by jaw movement, may become inadequate, and cerumen accumulation may cause pain, itching, tinnitus, or hearing loss.

When symptomatic, cerumen can be removed by topical cerumenolytics, irrigation, or manual removal. Topical agents and irrigation should be avoided in the presence of a perforated tympanic membrane; mechanical removal is preferred in these instances. The American Academy of Otolaryngology recommends counseling patients not to insert any foreign object into the ear canal because it can worsen cerumen impaction by pushing wax deeper into the canal, causing lacerations, trauma, and perforation of the tympanic membrane.

Epistaxis is a common problem affecting up to 60% of the U.S. population, with 6% of affected patients requiring medical attention. Ninety percent of epistaxis cases originate in the anterior nasal septum in the Kiesselbach plexus

. Posterior bleeding, although less common, is more likely to result in significant hemorrhage. The history should include assessment for timing and frequency of epistaxis, local trauma, nose picking, intranasal medications and anticoagulant/antiplatelet use, arid environments, infection, intranasal drug use (cocaine), family and personal history of bleeding disorders, and relevant comorbidities.

Anterior bleeding can be managed with compression of the alae (lower one third of the nose) for at least 5 minutes. If the bleeding site can be identified on anterior rhinoscopy, use of topical vasoconstrictors, such as oxymetazoline, and nasal cautery may be useful. If bleeding continues, nasal packing with an inflatable tamponade device or a foam polymer tampon may be necessary. Refractory or recurrent bleeding may rarely require embolization or surgical ligation in consultation with an otolaryngologist. Patients with recurrent bleeding or unilateral epistaxis should undergo nasal endoscopy. Patients with recurrent personal or family history of bilateral nosebleeds should be examined for oral mucosal or nasal telangiectasias, with consideration of referral to an otolaryngologist to rule out hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasias.

Posterior bleeding may cause substantial blood loss. Patients with persistent or recurrent bleeding not controlled by packing or nasal cauterization should be evaluated by an otolaryngologist for consideration of arterial ligation or endovascular embolization.
Anterior epistaxis can be managed with compression of the alae (lower one third of the nose) for at least 5 minutes.

Most upper respiratory tract infections are caused by viruses that infiltrate epithelial cells, leading to activation of inflammatory mechanisms that account for symptoms of fever, cough, and congestion caused by overproduction of mucosal secretions. Rhinoviruses are the cause of most cases of the common cold. Symptoms of uncomplicated infection may persist for up to 2 weeks after initial infection. Virus transmission is via inhalation or direct contact with secretions infected with viral particles. Hand hygiene through frequent washing or use of alcohol-based rubs is an effective means of preventing transmission. Treatment goals are focused on reducing the severity of discomfort caused by frequent coughing, sneezing, and subjective malaise. Antibiotic therapy is ineffective and is not recommended for either shortening duration of symptoms or preventing bacterial superinfection. Medical therapy should be directed by symptoms. Analgesics may help with myalgia and headache, whereas nasal symptoms may respond to intranasal cromolyn, intranasal ipratropium, or combination decongestant/antihistamines. There is little evidence to support the use of expectorants or mucolytics. Over-the-counter zinc-containing intranasal products should be avoided owing to the risk for permanent anosmia.

Acute rhinosinusitis presents with nasal congestion, purulent nasal discharge, facial pain/pressure, fever, or cough of less than 4 weeks' duration. Most cases are caused by viruses, allergies, or irritants. It is usually self-limited; therapies that may relieve symptoms include systemic decongestants, saline nasal irrigation, and intranasal glucocorticoids, all targeted to the patient's specific symptoms. Avoidance of unnecessary antibiotics represents high value care. Indications for antibiotic treatment and regimens are described in
. Patients who are seriously ill, deteriorate despite appropriate antibiotic therapy, or have recurrent episodes should be evaluated by an otolaryngologist.

Chronic sinusitis manifests with at least 12 weeks of nasal congestion with purulent drainage, diminished sense of smell, or facial pain or pressure. It may be associated with nasal polyposis (with a strong association with asthma). Demonstration of mucosal involvement by nasal endoscopy or imaging (typically CT) is necessary for diagnosis. Treatment includes glucocorticoids and antibiotics.

Allergic rhinitis involves sneezing, congestion, and rhinorrhea often linked to a seasonal allergen or other exposure. Nonallergic rhinitis occurs in response to nonallergic stimuli, such as spicy foods and irritants. First-line treatment of allergic and nonallergic rhinitis consists of avoiding precipitating factors and monotherapy with intranasal glucocorticoids. An intranasal antihistamine is another option; combination therapy with intranasal glucocorticoid and antihistamine may be used for more significant symptoms. Nonsedating oral antihistamines are another option. Leukotriene receptor antagonists are less effective and may cause adverse effects. Rhinitis medicamentosa is chronic rhinitis resulting from inappropriate long-term use of topical nasal decongestants. Treatment consists of cessation of the decongestant with the addition of intranasal glucocorticoids when needed.

Acute pharyngitis presents as sore throat that may worsen with swallowing; symptoms typically last less than 1 week. Most cases are viral in etiology; only 5% to 15% of pharyngitis cases are caused by bacteria, most often group A

Features suggesting the more common viral cause include concomitant cough, conjunctivitis, coryza, hoarseness, and oral ulcers. Patients with viral pharyngitis should be treated conservatively with symptom control (such as analgesics [NSAIDs or acetaminophen], lozenges or topical sprays, and increased environmental humidity). In bacterial pharyngitis, appropriate antibiotic treatment reduces the risk for rheumatic fever, suppurative complications (such as peritonsillar or retropharyngeal abscess), duration of symptoms, and transmission. The Centor criteria (fever by history, tonsillar exudates, tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy, and absence of cough) can help guide the need for testing and treatment of bacterial pharyngitis. Because the Centor criteria have a low positive predictive value for determining the presence of group A streptococcal infection, the best strategy may be to use the criteria to identify patients who have a low probability of infection. The Infectious Diseases Society of American suggests that patients with fewer than 3 Centor criteria do not need to be tested. Patients with a Centor score of 1 or less do not need to be tested; patients with two criteria can be considered for testing. Patients with three or more Centor criteria should be tested by using a rapid antigen detection test. Antibiotic treatment is reserved for patients with positive test results; penicillin and amoxicillin are first-line therapies. Throat culture should be considered in patients who are at high risk for complications (immunocompromised state) in the setting of high clinical suspicion but negative results on rapid antigen detection testing.

infection can cause Lemierre syndrome, a rare suppurative complication of pharyngitis caused by local spread of infection with resultant septic thrombosis of the internal jugular vein. Preexisting immunosuppression is not the rule, and it typically occurs in otherwise healthy young adults. Clinicians should suspect Lemierre syndrome in patients with severe pharyngitis and neck pain and in those who do not respond to appropriate antibiotics. Diagnosis is made with contrast CT of the neck.
Acute rhinosinusitis is usually caused by viruses, allergies, or irritants, and avoidance of unnecessary antibiotics represents high value care.
Patients with acute pharyngitis who present with fewer than three Centor criteria do not need to be tested or treated for bacterial pharyngitis.

Epiglottitis is a rare, severe inflammatory response to upper respiratory tract infection that can cause partial or complete airway obstruction; it requires emergent identification and intervention. Immunization with
type B vaccine has shifted the causative agents from this classic bacterial strain to a broad range of community-acquired respiratory pathogens, including

. Patients with epiglottitis typically appear seriously ill, with excessive salivation due to difficulty managing oral secretions, tachypnea and stridor, and severe odynophagia and dysphagia. Although adults with acute epiglottitis are less likely than children to progress to airway obstruction, if severe acute epiglottitis is suspected and airway obstruction seems imminent, airway control should precede diagnostic evaluation. On physical examination, the epiglottitis and surrounding structures appear hyperemic and engorged, occluding portions of the airway

. Radiographic imaging with ultrasonography or plain radiography may be helpful in gauging the severity of neck tissue inflammation and predicting likelihood of progression. Patients rarely require intubation or tracheostomy; hospital admission is recommended, often to an ICU setting and with surgical consultation, in the event that tracheostomy or intubation is required. Treatment consists of immediate parenteral antibiotic therapy and regular airway reassessment. Parenteral glucocorticoids may have a role in some cases to reduce airway inflammation, but their use is not yet standardized.
Treatment of epiglottitis consists of immediate parenteral antibiotic therapy and regular airway reassessment; intubation or tracheostomy is rarely required.

The salivary glands include the major (parotid, submandibular, and sublingual) salivary glands and thousands of minor salivary glands. Disorders of the salivary gland includes sialadenitis, salivary gland stones (sialolithiasis), and salivary gland tumors.

Acute sialadenitis typically presents with sudden onset of acute pain and swelling of the affected salivary gland and may be accompanied by fever, chills, and malaise. Sialadenitis typically has a bacterial cause, most commonly

; less common causes include viral infection (mumps, cytomegalovirus, HIV), mycobacterial infection, and recent radiation therapy. Conditions that decrease salivary flow increase the risk for sialadenitis; these include volume depletion, Sjögren syndrome, poor oral hygiene, sialolithiasis, malnourishment, prior radiation therapy, and use of anticholinergic medications. Physical examination often reveals tenderness and erythema over the affected gland. The parotid gland can be palpated from the earlobe forward to the gumline of the second upper molar, where the Stensen duct opens. The Wharton duct, the opening of the submandibular gland, can be felt along the floor or the mouth when palpating from posterior to anterior. Stones may be palpated and are typically tender, small, and hard, whereas tumors are typically firm and nontender. Manual palpation may result in pus exuding from the duct's orifice, whereas a healthy gland exudes clear saliva. Purulent drainage can be cultured to direct antibiotic therapy. An obstructed duct, however, will excrete no fluid on palpation. Management of sialadenitis and sialolithiasis includes stimulation of saliva production with warm compresses and sialagogues (sour candies or vitamin C lozenges); salivary gland massage; increased fluid intake; oral hygiene; and, in cases of bacterial sialadenitis, antibiotics. Recurrent sialolithiasis can result in chronic sialadenitis, and chronic obstruction can lead to salivary gland atrophy.

Salivary gland tumors most commonly present as a painless salivary gland mass; facial paralysis and lymphadenopathy increase concern for malignancy. Previous radiation therapy, smoking history, and viral infection (Epstein-Barr virus, HIV, human papillomavirus) are common causes. Contrast-enhanced CT or MRI and tissue biopsy, typically with fine-needle aspiration, are the first steps in evaluation.

Management of sialadenitis and sialolithiasis includes stimulation of saliva production with warm compresses and sialagogues (sour candies or vitamin C lozenges); salivary gland massage; increased fluid intake; oral hygiene; and, in cases of bacterial sialadenitis, antibiotics.

Poor oral hygiene is one of most common chronic conditions in the United States and affects overall health and quality of life. Dental caries are caused by bacteria. Certain foods and beverages (especially those containing sugar) leave bacteria in the mouth, creating an acidic environment that erodes enamel and dentin, causing tooth sensitivity or pain and inflammation. The stained pits and fissures of dental caries can be seen on examination

. Pulpitis occurs when the erosion extends down to the pulp cavity, requiring removal of the caries and placement of a filling. If untreated, the erosion can affect the root or cause periodontitis requiring root canal or tooth extraction, or an abscess requiring incision and drainage.

Ludwig angina is a life-threatening infection of the floor of the mouth and should be suspected in patients with submandibular swelling and edema of the mouth floor, drooling, neck pain, dysphagia, or dysphonia. Ludwig angina often originates from the second and third lower molar teeth and can cause airway obstruction caused by supraglottic edema. The causative pathogen is usually
Treatment requires urgent CT; blood cultures; airway management precautions; broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy; and, if indicated, surgical drainage.

Nearly half of U.S. adults have periodontal disease, which is associated with increased risk for diabetes and cardiovascular disease. Gingivitis (inflammation of the gums) is the initial manifestation of periodontal disease

. Gingivitis is reversible with routine dental visits and cleanings, brushing with fluoride toothpaste, flossing, fluoride varnish anticavity treatment, and use of chlorhexidine oral rinses. Periodontitis affects the periodontal ligament and presents with halitosis, inflamed gums that bleed easily, tooth sensitivity, and pain. Treatment is the same as that for gingivitis with the addition of scaling and root planing.

Necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis, formerly called Vincent angina, is characterized by halitosis, oral pain, and ulcerated and necrotic areas of the tonsils and gingiva with red irregular edges that may create a grayish pseudomembrane that bleeds if scraped

. Lymph nodes may be enlarged and tender. This is usually seen in patients with poor oral hygiene or malnutrition, or who smoke. Treatment includes oral antibiotics; twice-daily chlorhexidine rinses for 2 weeks; and, if severe, debridement.

Dental fracture is an emergency because a tooth becomes nonviable 1 hour after fracture. Patients should handle the tooth by the crown, wash it in cold water, reposition it in the socket, and bite gently on a washcloth to help keep the tooth in place until seen by a dental professional. If immediate repositioning is not possible, the tooth should be placed in cold pasteurized milk while seeking immediate care by a dental professional.
Gingivitis is reversible with routine dental visits and cleanings, brushing with fluoride toothpaste, flossing, fluoride varnish anticavity treatment, and use of chlorhexidine oral rinses.
Bauer CA. Tinnitus. N Engl J Med. 2018;378:1224-31.
Chandrasekhar SS, Tsai Do BS, Schwartz SR, et al. Clinical practice guideline: sudden hearing loss (update). Otolaryngol Head Neck Surg. 2019;161(1_suppl):S1-45.
Cunningham LL, Tucci DL. Hearing loss in adults. N Engl J Med. 2017;377:2465-73.

Harris AM, Hicks LA, Qaseem A; High Value Care Task Force of the American College of Physicians and for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Appropriate antibiotic use for acute respiratory tract infection in adults: advice for high-value care from the American College of Physicians and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
Klein MR. Infections of the oropharynx. Emerg Med Clin North Am. 2019;37:69-80.
Nieman CL, Oh ES. Hearing loss.
Ogle OE. Salivary gland diseases. Dent Clin North Am. 2020;64:87-104.
Rosenfeld RM, Schwartz SR, Cannon CR, et al. Clinical practice guideline: acute otitis externa. Otolaryngol Head Neck Surg. 2014;150:S1-24.
Schwartz SR, Magit AE, Rosenfeld RM, et al. Clinical practice guideline (update): earwax (cerumen impaction). Otolaryngol Head Neck Surg. 2017;156:S1-29.
Stephens MB, Wiedemer JP, Kushner GM. Dental problems in primary care. Am Fam Physician. 2018;98:654-60.
Tunkel DE, Anne S, Payne SC, et al. Clinical Practice Guideline: nosebleed (epistaxis) executive summary. Otolaryngol Head Neck Surg. 2020;162:8-25.
May completely obstruct the ear canal
Associated with overgrowth of bone in the middle ear
Abnormal growth of keratinized squamous epithelium in the middle ear (see Figure 23)
Age-related hearing loss; often symmetric, high-frequency loss
Classically, triad of sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo; not all are necessarily present at once, may fluctuate
Benign tumor of Schwann cell sheath surrounding the vestibular or cochlear nerve
May be related to chronic noise exposure or sudden, short noise blast exposure
Mixed or Causing Either Conductive or Sensorineural Hearing Loss
May be caused by ossicular disruption, leading to conductive hearing loss, or by auditory nerve injury, causing sensorineural hearing loss

footnotes: Conductive hearing loss is inadequate mechanical transmission of sound through the tympanic membrane and ossicles of the middle ear.
Sensorineural hearing loss is deficit or injury of the vestibulocochlear nerve.

children: Positive LR for >25 dB Hearing Loss
Negative LR for >25 dB Hearing Loss
Patient answers “yes” or “no” to the following question: “Do you feel you have hearing loss?” or “Would you say that you have any difficulty hearing?”
Hearing Handicap Inventory for the Elderly–Screening Version
Patient answers a 10-item question set, with options of “yes,” “no,” or “sometimes.”
The examiner gently rubs two fingers together at a distance of 15 cm (6 in) from the patient's ear. A positive result is failure to respond to two or more of six finger rubs.

The examiner stands 2 ft from patient's ear and masks the untested ear by occluding the canal and rubbing the tragus. The examiner whispers six sets of three letter, number, or word combinations. A positive test result is the inability to repeat three sets correctly.
The examiner holds a ticking watch at a distance of 15 cm (6 in) from patient's ear. A positive result is failure to respond to two or more of six presentations of the ticking watch.

The examiner holds the device in the patient's ear while the patient indicates awareness of each tone. A positive test result is a failure to identify the 1000-Hz or 2000-Hz frequency in both ears or the 1000-Hz and 2000-Hz frequency in one ear.

title.__html: Distinguishing Between Conductive and Sensorineural Hearing Loss With the Weber and Rinne Tests

children: Distinguishing Between Conductive and Sensorineural Hearing Loss With the Weber and Rinne Tests
Decreased in the affected ear (bone conduction > air conduction)
As loud or louder in the affected ear (air conduction > bone conduction)

footnotes: A 256-Hz vibrating tuning fork (although a 512-Hz tuning fork may be used) is applied to the forehead or scalp at the midline, and the patient is asked if the sound is louder in one ear or the other; a normal test result shows no lateralization.

A 512-Hz vibrating tuning fork is applied to the mastoid process of the affected ear until it is no longer heard. The fork is then repositioned outside of the external auditory canal, and the patient is asked if he or she can again hear the tuning fork; with a normal test result, air conduction is greater than bone conduction, and the tuning fork can be heard.

children: Onset of severe symptoms or signs of high fever >39 °C (102.2 °F) with purulent nasal discharge or facial pain lasting for ≥3 consecutive days
Onset of worsening symptoms after a typical viral illness that lasted 5 days after initially improving (“double sickening”)

footnotes: There is limited evidence to guide therapy, particularly in adults, and guidelines from major professional societies differ.
Adjunctive therapy, such as intranasal saline irrigation or intranasal glucocorticoids, has been shown to alleviate symptoms and potentially decrease antibiotic use.
